page.title: 17LONGSTANTON ATTITUDES
page.content: 19th-Century Longstanton was split on religious grounds : Church or chapel. We wondered what might divide it now. Certainly there seem to be opportunities for divisions. Longstanton's shape, with its two distinct "ends"; its six-fold growth in 50 years; the presence through the army of so many short-stay "outsiders" -all these might mean factions and social strains. We did indeed hear of 'cliques'. St.Michael's residents, we were told, felt separate from All Saints'. There were few true village people, many newcomers . Young wives joined the Wives' Club, not the Women's Institute. And many army families tended not to give their time to village matters ...... We heard all these things, and we also heard they did not exist. Perhaps people see only what they want to see?
